instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A2289: What is A2289? A2289 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2020 with EMC 3456, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01987..
definitions.820-01987: What is 820-01987? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V3_G3H_RTC? PP3V3_G3H_RTC Is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.PP1V1_SLPS2R: What is PP1V1_SLPS2R? The PP1V1_SLPS2R power rail in the MacBook schematic provides a 1.1-volt supply in a specific low-power state indicated by the "_SLPS2R" suffix and is used for powering the T2 chip..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid 20V 0A
threads.message:
Got this board slightly water damaged, It is stuck at 20V 0A.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 12,60V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is 0V and no short diode mode is 

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_PMU_VDDMAIN</SIGNAL> 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> 1.1V
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_SLPDDR</SIGNAL> 1.1V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> 1.8V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_AWAKE</SIGNAL> 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> 5V
<SIGNAL>PMU_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> 3.3 V

I must admit I really don't know at this point what signals are required for the PMIC to switch <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> or what condition before even getting <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>.

Thanks

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid 20V 0A
threads.message:
Inspect the board under microscope for corrosion.
Try DFU mode, just for test.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid 20V 0A
threads.message:
Yes I actually started with a good inspection on both sides of the board I don't see any corrosion.
I tried DFU mode Revive and Restore and it ends up with Error 4005 (can't restore the target ...gave up waiting) 
Nothing change...Thanks

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid 20V 0A
threads.message: Maybe accumulated crap underneath T2 chip.
